quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
puts "58" == 5
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

[b][/b]A Boolean comparison using the == operator returns [b]true [/b]when two operands are equal, and [b]false [/b]when they are not:[code format="rb" codeId="987"]a = 5
b = 8

puts a [b]==[/b] b # [b]false[/b]

puts a [b]==[/b] 5 # [b]true[/b][/code]
[note]Be careful not to confuse [b]assignment [/b](one equals sign) with [b]comparison [/b](two equals signs).[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
a = 7
b = a/2
puts b == (a-4)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

Another comparison operator, the [b]not equal operator[/b] (!=), evaluates to true if the items being compared aren't equal, and false if they are. 
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="988"]a = 8
b = 7

puts a [b]!=[/b] b # [b]true[/b][/code]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
puts 7 > 7.0
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comparison[/h1]

Ruby also has operators that determine whether one value is greater than or less than another. These operators are > and < respectively. Similarly, the greater than or equal to, and less than or equal to operators are >= and <=.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="989"]puts 12 > 8 # true

puts 5 < 2 # false

puts 5 >= 5.0 # true

puts 3 <= 6 # true[/code]
There is also the [b].eql?[/b] method, which results in true only if both arguments have the [b]same type and equal values[/b]. 
[b]For example:[/b][code format="rb" codeId="990"]puts 3 == 3.0 # true 
# but
puts 3.[b]eql?[/b](3.0) # false[/code]
3.eql?(3.0) is [b]false [/b]because 3 is an integer and 3.0 is a float.
[note]Greater than and less than operators can also be used to compare strings [b]lexicographically [/b](the alphabetical order of words is based on the alphabetical order of their component letters).[/note]
